brmstools
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Forest plots for brmsfit models with varying effects
    • Panel and spaghetti plots
  • News

    brmstools

    brmstools provides convenient plotting and post-processing functions for brmsfit objects (bayesian regression models fitted with the brms R package).

    library(brmstools)
#> Loading required package: ggplot2
#> Loading required package: brms
#> Loading required package: Rcpp
#> Loading 'brms' package (version 2.0.1). Useful instructions
#> can be found by typing help('brms'). A more detailed introduction
#> to the package is available through vignette('brms_overview').
#> Run theme_set(theme_default()) to use the default bayesplot theme.

    brmstools is in beta version so will probably break down with some inputs: Suggestions for improvements and bug reports are warmly welcomed.

    brms makes it easy to fit (complex) models with Stan. The flexible brms::marginal_effects() and brms::plot() methods allow various visualizations of fitted brms models. However, I found myself repeatedly writing code for spaghetti, forest, and panel plots, all of which are difficult to create with built-in brms functions. This package provides functions for easily creating these types of figures, and other miscellaneous helper functions for post-processing brmsfit models.

    Forest plots

    Notably, forest() draws forest plots for meta-analytic and multilevel models:

    forest(fit_rem, digits=0)
#> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.0227

    Panel plots

    panels() draws panel plots:

    panels(fit_ml, xvar = "Days")

    Spaghetti plots

    spaghetti() draws spaghetti plots:

    spaghetti(fit_ml, xvar = "Days")

    Examples and instructions can be found at https://mvuorre.github.io/brmstools.
